ai_news.title: AI in the News
ai_news.summary: The AI landscape in February 2026 reflects a market maturing beyond hype cycles into tangible friction points and institutional reckoning. On the positive front, technical progress continues: Wolfram is integrating with LLM systems, distillation techniques are scaling across vendors like DeepSeek and Moonshot, and practical applications emerge—from FreeBSD drivers to Ladybird's Rust migration. However, three critical tensions are surfacing. First, economic reality: Goldman Sachs reported AI contributed "basically zero" to US growth last year, tempering productivity claims. Second, trust and safety issues are compounding—AI-generated content is drowning platforms like Pinterest in spam, verbatim copyright violations are emerging from training data, and synthetic social media replies are degrading user experience. Third, disruption anxiety is real: IBM's stock fell following Anthropic's COBOL targeting, while freight consolidation signals industry restructuring. Institutionally, skepticism is hardening. The Pope instructed priests to think independently rather than delegate homilies to AI. Browser makers like Firefox are adding kill switches. Anthropic's education initiative (AI Fluency Index) suggests the industry recognizes users need better literacy, not more adoption. The narrative isn't triumphalism—it's a field confronting its limitations while consolidation accelerates among enterprises capable of AI integration. The question shifting from "will AI work?" to "at what cost to institutions and labor?"

items.title: Firefox 148 Launches with AI Kill Switch Feature and More Enhancements
items.why_it_matters: Browser-level AI controls are becoming a consumer expectation as Firefox adds user-facing toggles for AI features, reflecting growing demand for AI governance at the application layer.

items.title: Ladybird adopts Rust, with help from AI
items.why_it_matters: The Ladybird browser project's adoption of Rust with AI assistance demonstrates how AI tooling is being integrated into the development of foundational infrastructure projects.

items.title: Pope tells priests to use their brains, not AI, to write homilies
items.why_it_matters: Religious institutions are explicitly rejecting AI for content creation in favor of human judgment, signaling institutional skepticism about AI's role in specialized knowledge domains.

items.title: FreeBSD doesn't have Wi-Fi driver for my old MacBook, so AI built one for me
items.why_it_matters: Community members are using AI to generate missing hardware drivers for legacy systems, illustrating AI's practical value in addressing infrastructure gaps where commercial incentives are absent.

items.title: AI Added 'Basically Zero' to US Economic Growth Last Year, Goldman Sachs Says
items.why_it_matters: Goldman Sachs' assessment that AI contributed negligibly to US economic growth in 2025 challenges prevailing assumptions about AI's near-term productivity impact on the broader economy.

items.title: Making Wolfram tech available as a foundation tool for LLM systems
items.why_it_matters: Wolfram is positioning its technology as foundational infrastructure for LLM systems, indicating a shift toward modular AI architectures built on specialized computational tools.

items.title: Anthropic announces proof of distillation at scale by MiniMax, DeepSeek,Moonshot
items.why_it_matters: Proof of distillation at scale by multiple vendors (MiniMax, DeepSeek, Moonshot) suggests model compression techniques are maturing, with implications for deployment efficiency.

items.title: Show HN: AI Timeline – 171 LLMs from Transformer (2017) to GPT-5.3 (2026)
items.why_it_matters: A timeline cataloging 171 LLM releases from 2017 to 2026 provides quantitative data on the acceleration of model development across the industry.

items.title: IBM Plunges After Anthropic's Latest Update Takes on COBOL
items.why_it_matters: IBM's stock decline following Anthropic's COBOL-targeting update indicates market concern about AI displacement of legacy enterprise systems and established vendor relationships.

items.title: AIs can generate near-verbatim copies of novels from training data
items.why_it_matters: AI systems generating near-verbatim copies of training data raises unresolved questions about copyright liability and the boundaries of permissible model behavior.

items.title: Pinterest is drowning in a sea of AI slop and auto-moderation
items.why_it_matters: Pinterest's content moderation crisis driven by AI-generated spam indicates that current automated moderation systems are insufficient for platform-scale content filtering.

items.title: Reuters AI News | Latest Headlines and Developments | Reuters
items.why_it_matters: Industry consolidation driven by AI adoption suggests competitive dynamics in logistics are shifting toward larger operators with greater capacity for AI integration.

items.title: AI is destroying open source, and it's not even good yet [video]
items.why_it_matters: Criticism that AI is degrading open-source quality reflects concerns about automated contributions and their impact on maintainability and project integrity.

items.title: Anthropic Education the AI Fluency Index
items.why_it_matters: Anthropic's AI Fluency Index represents an effort to establish standardized measurement for human understanding of AI capabilities and limitations.

items.title: AI-generated replies really are a scourge these days
items.why_it_matters: Widespread complaints about AI-generated social media replies indicate user perception problems with synthetic content quality and authenticity at scale.
